verses.text: After this, Absalom the son of David had a beautiful sister, whose name was Tamar. And Amnon, the son of David, loved her.
verses.comment: Some manuscripts clarify that Tamar and Absalom are full siblings; Amnon is their half-brother.

verses.text: And Amnon was so distressed over his sister Tamar that he made himself sick, for she was a virgin, and it seemed impossible to Amnon to do anything to her.
verses.comment: Phrase 'do anything to her' literally means 'to do anything with her'; context indicates wrong intention.

verses.text: But Amnon had a friend whose name was Jonadab, the son of Shimeah, David's brother. And Jonadab was a very crafty man.
verses.comment: 'Crafty' renders 'wise' or 'shrewd,' but with a negative connotation here.

verses.text: He said to him, 'O son of the king, why are you so dejected morning after morning? Will you not tell me?' Amnon said to him, 'I love Tamar, my brother Absalom's sister.'
verses.comment: 'My brother Absalom's sister' clarifies the relationship.

verses.text: Then Jonadab said to him, 'Lie down on your bed and pretend to be sick. And when your father comes to see you, say to him, “Please let my sister Tamar come and give me food to eat, and prepare the food in my sight, so that I may see it and eat it from her hand.”'
verses.comment: Direct speech; preserves the original plan's details.

verses.text: So Amnon lay down and pretended to be sick. When the king came to see him, Amnon said to the king, 'Please let my sister Tamar come and make a couple of cakes in my sight, that I may eat from her hand.'
verses.comment: 'Cakes': literal 'heart-shaped cakes'; likely a kind of bread or pastry.

verses.text: Then David sent home to Tamar, saying, 'Go to your brother Amnon’s house and prepare food for him.'
verses.comment: David’s order repeats the ruse; 'prepare food' is idiomatic for 'make food.'

verses.text: So Tamar went to her brother Amnon’s house, where he was lying down. And she took dough, kneaded it, made cakes in his sight, and baked the cakes.
verses.comment: Follows sequence of original Hebrew verbs closely.

verses.text: Then she took the pan and emptied them out before him, but he refused to eat. And Amnon said, 'Send out everyone from me.' So everyone went out from him.
verses.comment: 'Emptied them out' literally, 'poured them out'; indicates placing food before him.

verses.text: Then Amnon said to Tamar, 'Bring the food into the bedroom, so that I may eat from your hand.' So Tamar took the cakes she had made and brought them into the bedroom to Amnon her brother.
But when she brought them near him to eat, he seized her and said to her, 'Come, lie with me, my sister.'
verses.comment: Translation keeps literal wording; 'lie with me' is biblical idiom for sexual union.

verses.text: But she answered him, 'No, my brother! Do not violate me, for such a thing is not done in Israel; do not do this disgraceful thing.'
verses.comment: 'Violate' translates 'do not humble me'; 'disgraceful thing' is literally 'folly.'

verses.text: 'As for me, where could I carry my shame? And as for you, you would be as one of the wicked fools in Israel. Now therefore, please speak to the king, for he will not withhold me from you.'
verses.comment: 'You would be as one of the fools'—'Fool' denotes moral rebellion and disgrace.

verses.text: But he would not listen to her, and being stronger than she, he violated her and lay with her.
verses.comment: Literal translation; 'violated' for 'forced.'

verses.text: Then Amnon hated her with a very great hatred, so that the hatred with which he hated her was greater than the love with which he had loved her. And Amnon said to her, 'Get up, go away!'
verses.comment: Wordplay between love and hate is retained from Hebrew.

verses.text: But she said to him, 'No, my brother, for this wrong in sending me away is greater than the other that you did to me.' But he would not listen to her.
verses.comment: 'Wrong' translates 'evil'; the expulsion compounded the trauma.

verses.text: He called the young man who served him and said, 'Put this woman out from me, and bolt the door after her.'
verses.comment: 'This woman' is dismissive in Hebrew.

verses.text: Now she was wearing a long robe with sleeves, for this was the kind of garment the virgin daughters of the king wore. So his servant put her out and bolted the door after her.
verses.comment: 'Long robe with sleeves’—the precise meaning is uncertain, but denotes a garment marking status as a virgin princess.

verses.text: Then Tamar put ashes on her head and tore the long robe that she wore. She laid her hand on her head and went away, crying aloud as she went.
verses.comment: Typical ancient signs of mourning and shame.

verses.text: And her brother Absalom said to her, 'Has Amnon your brother been with you? But now, my sister, be quiet; he is your brother. Do not take this matter to heart.' So Tamar lived, a desolate woman, in her brother Absalom’s house.
verses.comment: Absalom’s words reflect the difficult social realities of the time, not approval.

verses.text: When King David heard all these things, he was very angry.
verses.comment: Text does not record David as taking action.

verses.text: But Absalom spoke to Amnon neither good nor bad, for Absalom hated Amnon because he had violated his sister Tamar.
verses.comment: Literal rendering; 'neither good nor bad' means no interaction at all.

verses.text: Two years later, when Absalom was shearing his sheep at Baal Hazor, near Ephraim, Absalom invited all the king’s sons.
verses.comment: Sheep-shearing was a time of feasting.

verses.text: And Absalom came to the king and said, 'Your servant has sheep shearers. Please let the king and his servants go with your servant.'
But the king said to Absalom, 'No, my son, let us not all go, so we will not be a burden to you.' He pressed him, but he would not go, yet he gave him his blessing.
Then Absalom said, 'If not, please let my brother Amnon go with us.' And the king said to him, 'Why should he go with you?'
verses.comment: 'Why should he go?' is suspicious; Hebrew makes David seem cautious.

verses.text: But Absalom pressed him until he let Amnon and all the king’s sons go with him.

Then Absalom commanded his servants, 'Mark when Amnon’s heart is merry with wine, and when I say to you, “Strike Amnon,” then kill him. Do not be afraid; have I not commanded you? Be strong and be courageous.'
verses.comment: 'Be strong and courageous' is a stock phrase for bold action (cf. Josh. 1:6).

verses.text: So Absalom’s servants did to Amnon as Absalom had commanded. Then all the king’s sons rose, and each mounted his mule and fled.
verses.comment: Mules were royal mounts.

verses.text: While they were on the way, news came to David, 'Absalom has struck down all the king’s sons, and not one of them is left.'
verses.comment: Initial report is exaggerated or mistaken.

verses.text: Then the king arose and tore his garments and lay on the ground, and all his servants who were standing by tore their garments.
verses.comment: Ancient mourning custom.

verses.text: But Jonadab, the son of Shimeah, David’s brother, said, 'Let not my lord suppose they have killed all the young men, the king’s sons; for Amnon alone is dead. For Absalom has determined this since the day he violated his sister Tamar.'
verses.comment: Jonadab knows the details; Hebrew indicates 'set his mind' or 'fixed in his heart.'

verses.text: 'Now therefore, let not my lord the king take the matter to heart, as if all the king’s sons are dead. For Amnon alone is dead.'
But Absalom had fled. And the young man who kept watch lifted up his eyes and looked, and behold, many people were coming by the road behind him on the hillside.
verses.comment: 'Watchman' was standard lookout on the wall.

verses.text: And Jonadab said to the king, 'Behold, the king’s sons have come; as your servant said, so it has come to pass.'
As soon as he had finished speaking, behold, the king’s sons came and lifted up their voice and wept. And the king also and all his servants wept very bitterly.
But Absalom fled and went to Talmai the son of Ammihud, king of Geshur. And David mourned for his son day after day.
verses.comment: Talmai was Absalom’s maternal grandfather; Geshur was outside David’s jurisdiction.

verses.text: So Absalom fled and went to Geshur, and was there three years.
verses.comment: 'Geshur' was a small Aramean kingdom.

verses.text: And the spirit of the king longed to go out to Absalom, for he was comforted concerning Amnon, since he was dead.
verses.comment: Hebrew is ambiguous: could mean David’s heart was set on Absalom, or that he had given up on him; translated as longing for him.
